metadata.meta: Cytotoxic isoferulic acidamide from Myricaria germanica (Tamaricaceae).
See comment in PubMed Commons below

Tamgermanitin, a unique N-trans-Isoferuloyltyramine, together with the hitherto unknown polyphenolics, 2,4-di-O-galloyl-(α/β)-glucopyranose and kaempferide 3,7-disulphate have been isolated from the leaf aqueous ethanol extract of the false tamarisk, Myricaria germanica DESV. In addition, 18 known phenolics were also separated and characterized. All structures were elucidated on the basis of detailed analysis of 1D- (1)H and (13)C NMR, COSY, HSQC, HMBC and HRFTESIMS spectral data. The extract, its chromatographic column fractions and the isolated isoferuloyltyramine, tamgermanetin demonstrated potential cytotoxic effect against three different tumor cell lines, namely liver (Huh-7), breast (MCF-7) and prostate (PC-3). The IC 50''s were found to be substantially low with low-resistance possibility. DNA flow-cytometic analysis indicated that column fractions and tamgermanetin enhanced pre-G apoptotic fraction. Both materials showed inhibiting activity against PARP enzyme activity. In conclusion, we report the isolation and identification of a novel compound, tamgermanitin, from the aqueous ethanol extract of Myricaria germanica leaves. Further, different fractions of the extract and tamgermanitin exhibit potent cytotoxic activities which warrant further investigations.

See comment in PubMed Commons belowPlant Signal Behav. 2013 Jan;8(1):e22642. doi: 10.4161/psb.22642. Epub 2012 Nov 3.Cytotoxic isoferulic acidamide from Myricaria germanica (Tamaricaceae).Nawwar MA1, Swilam NF2, Hashim AN1, Al-Abd AM3, Abdel-Naim AB4, Lindequist U2.Author information1Department of Phytochemistry and Plant Systematic; National Research Center; Dokki, Cairo, Egypt.2Institute for Pharmacy; Pharmaceutical Biology; Ernst-Moritz-Arndt-University Greifswald; Greifswald, Germany.3Department of Pharmacology; National Research Center; Dokki, Cairo, Egypt.4Department of Pharmacology and Toxicology; Ain Shams University; Cairo, Egypt.AbstractTamgermanitin, a unique N-trans-Isoferuloyltyramine, together with the hitherto unknown polyphenolics, 2,4-di-O-galloyl-(α/β)-glucopyranose and kaempferide 3,7-disulphate have been isolated from the leaf aqueous ethanol extract of the false tamarisk, Myricaria germanica DESV. In addition, 18 known phenolics were also separated and characterized. All structures were elucidated on the basis of detailed analysis of 1D- (1)H and (13)C NMR, COSY, HSQC, HMBC and HRFTESIMS spectral data. The extract, its chromatographic column fractions and the isolated isoferuloyltyramine, tamgermanetin demonstrated potential cytotoxic effect against three different tumor cell lines, namely liver (Huh-7), breast (MCF-7) and prostate (PC-3). The IC 50''s were found to be substantially low with low-resistance possibility. DNA flow-cytometic analysis indicated that column fractions and tamgermanetin enhanced pre-G apoptotic fraction. Both materials showed inhibiting activity against PARP enzyme activity. In conclusion, we report the isolation and identification of a novel compound, tamgermanitin, from the aqueous ethanol extract of Myricaria germanica leaves. Further, different fractions of the extract and tamgermanitin exhibit potent cytotoxic activities which warrant further investigations. KEYWORDS: 2,4-di-O-galloyl-(α/β)-glucopyranose; Myricaria germanica; N-trans-Isoferuloyltyramine; cytotoxicity; kaempferide 3,7-disulphate; tamgermanitinPMID: 23123452 [PubMed - indexed for MEDLINE] PMCID: PMC3745567 Free PMC ArticleShareImages from this publication.See all images (6)Free textFigure 4. Compound 2. Kaempferide 3,7-disodium sulfate.Cytotoxic isoferulic acidamide from Myricaria germanica (Tamaricaceae)Plant Signal Behav. 2013 January 1;8(1):e22642.Figure 5. Compound 12. 2,4-di-O-(α/β) galloyl glucopyranose.Cytotoxic isoferulic acidamide from Myricaria germanica (Tamaricaceae)Plant Signal Behav. 2013 January 1;8(1):e22642.Figure 6. Tamgermanetin. N-trans-3-hydroxy 4-methoxy cinnamoyltyramine.Cytotoxic isoferulic acidamide from Myricaria germanica (Tamaricaceae)Plant Signal Behav. 2013 January 1;8(1):e22642.Figure 1. Effect of tamarixellagic acid and tamgermanitin on the cell cycle distribution of Huh-7 cells. Cells were exposed to tamarixellagic acid (B) and tamgermanitin (C) for 24 h and compared with control cells (A). Cell cycle distribution was determined using DNA cytometry analysis and different cell phases were plotted (D) as percent of total events (n = 3).Cytotoxic isoferulic acidamide from Myricaria germanica (Tamaricaceae)Plant Signal Behav. 2013 January 1;8(1):e22642.Figure 2. Effect of tamarixellagic acid and tamgermanitin on the cell cycle distribution of MCF-7 cells. Cells were exposed to tamarixellagic acid (B) and tamgermanitin (C) for 24 h and compared with control cells (A). Cell cycle distribution was determined using DNA cytometry analysis and different cell phases were plotted (D) as percent of total events (n = 3).Cytotoxic isoferulic acidamide from Myricaria germanica (Tamaricaceae)Plant Signal Behav. 2013 January 1;8(1):e22642.Figure 3. Effect of tamarixellagic acid and tamgermanitin on PARP (A) and caspase-3 (B) enzyme activity was assessed in cell-free system and in Huh-7 cell, respectively. Data are presented as mean ± SEM; (n = 3).Cytotoxic isoferulic acidamide from Myricaria germanica (Tamaricaceae)Plant Signal Behav. 2013 January 1;8(1):e22642.Publication Types, MeSH Terms, SubstancesPublication TypesResearch Support, Non-U.S. Gov'tMeSH TermsApoptosisBreast Neoplasms/drug therapy*Cell ProliferationCoumaric Acids/chemistryCoumaric Acids/isolation & purificationCoumaric Acids/pharmacologyCoumaric Acids/therapeutic use*HumansInhibitory Concentration 50Liver Neoplasms/drug therapy*MCF-7 CellsMaleMolecular StructurePhytotherapy*Plant Extracts/chemistryPlant Extracts/isolation & purificationPlant Extracts/pharmacologyPlant Extracts/therapeutic use*Plant LeavesPoly(ADP-ribose) Polymerases/antagonists & inhibitorsPolyphenols/chemistryPolyphenols/isolation & purificationPolyphenols/pharmacologyPolyphenols/therapeutic useProstatic Neoplasms/drug therapy*Tamaricaceae/chemistry*Tyramine/analogs & derivatives*Tyramine/chemistryTyramine/isolation & purificationTyramine/pharmacologyTyramine/therapeutic useSubstancesCoumaric AcidsN-(3-hydroxy-4-methoxycinnamoyl)tyraminePlant ExtractsPolyphenolsPoly(ADP-ribose) PolymerasesTyramineLinkOut - more resourcesFull Text SourcesEurope PubMed CentralPubMed CentralPubMed Central CanadaOther Literature SourcesAccess more work from the authors - ResearchGateMedicalBreast Cancer - MedlinePlus Health InformationHerbal Medicine - MedlinePlus Health InformationLiver Cancer - MedlinePlus Health InformationProstate Cancer - MedlinePlus Health InformationMiscellaneousTYRAMINE - Hazardous Substances Data BankPubMed Commons home PubMed Commons 0 commentsHow to join PubMed CommonsHow to cite this comment:
